title: Null Space, Column Space, and Linear Transformations

sections.title: Introduction (Wide Shot)
sections.content: Hey everyone, I’m Jihad Al Sayed. In this episode, we’re breaking down three powerful ideas: the null space, the column space, and how they connect to linear transformations. This is where theory meets application.

sections.title: What is the Null Space?
sections.content: The null space of a matrix A is the set of all vectors x that satisfy Ax = 0. It's a subspace of the domain of A and tells us about the solution set to homogeneous systems.

sections.title: What is the Column Space?
sections.content: The column space is the span of the columns of A. It’s the set of all vectors that A can map to — in other words, all possible outputs Ax = b.

sections.title: Visual Connection to Transformations
sections.content: If you think of A as a transformation, the null space is what's collapsed to zero, and the column space is where things end up.

sections.title: Dimension Link: Rank-Nullity Theorem
sections.math: \text{dim(Null A)} + \text{dim(Col A)} = \text{number of columns of A}

sections.title: Real-World Examples
sections.content: In computer science, the null space helps us find redundant or unnecessary variables. The column space relates directly to whether a system of equations is solvable.

sections.title: Recap
sections.content: We’ve explored how the null space and column space define the core behavior of a matrix transformation. This is foundational for solving systems, compressing data, and even designing neural networks.
